elements.content: Integrating nanozymes with natural enzymes to form cascade reactions is one of the most promising ways to develop biocatalysts with versatile performance; however, the applicability of the cascade is typically hampered by the instability of enzymes and the hindrance of mass transfer in the host environment. Utilizing amorphous ZIF-90 (aZIF-90) as a host material, herein, we have reported a one-pot way to encapsulate glucose oxidase (GOx) and magnetic nanoparticles (MNP) to form GOx/MNP@aZIF-90. We reasoned that the amorphous structure of ZIF-90 not only provides a protected environment to confine the cascade reaction but also generates mesopores and internal voids to improve the performance of the enzymatic cascade. The catalytic activity of aZIF-90 was almost 4 times higher than that of crystalline composites, and the residual activity was higher than 80% after being stored for 9 days. This is the first time that GOx and MNP were simultaneously confined in aZIF-90 with mesopores, which suggested that an amorphous metal–organic framework is promising in the development of an enzymatic cascade.

We reasoned that the amorphous structure of ZIF-90 not only provides a protected environment to confine the cascade reaction but also generates mesopores and internal voids to improve the performance of the enzymatic cascade. elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are a species of microporous crystalline materials synthesized from certain organic linkers and specific metal ions. MOFs possess a series of characteristics like large surface area, large pore volumes, tunable topological structure, and high pH/thermal/chemical stability. MOFs have attracted tremendous research interest, and have exhibited promising applications in the expansive fields of drug delivery, catalysis, and separation. Particularly, MOFs can function as a robust hosting material for catalysis; for example, the recent work of Ma et al. demonstrated that MOFs can be engineered as single-atom catalysts for nitrogen dioxide reduction. Moreover, MOFs have been recognized as an excellent carrier for the protection of biomolecules from denaturation and degradation. The amorphous MOFs (aMOFs) with disordered and fuzzy structures had been utilized as a host of enzymes, which maintained a higher activity of enzymes than that in crystalline MOFs and showed good stability. Compared with other enzyme immobilization carriers, such as polymeric matrices, nanomaterials, porous materials, and microcapsules, aMOFs can reduce the leach of the enzyme, enzyme denaturation, and the restricted mass transfer efficiency, and can improve the operational stability of enzymes in harsh environments. aMOFs can be synthesized through the amorphization of MOFs, such as pressure/heat-induced amorphization, mechanical milling-induced amorphization, chemical treatment-induced amorphization, and the direct synthesis of aMOFs. However, most approaches need harsh conditions to synthesize aMOFs, which are detrimental to biomacromolecules. Thus, a mild method is necessary for the immobilization of enzymes.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are a species of microporous crystalline materials synthesized from certain organic linkers and specific metal ions. MOFs possess a series of characteristics like large surface area, large pore volumes, tunable topological structure, and high pH/thermal/chemical stability. MOFs have attracted tremendous research interest, and have exhibited promising applications in the expansive fields of drug delivery, catalysis, and separation. Particularly, MOFs can function as a robust hosting material for catalysis; for example, the recent work of Ma et al. demonstrated that MOFs can be engineered as single-atom catalysts for nitrogen dioxide reduction. Moreover, MOFs have been recognized as an excellent carrier for the protection of biomolecules from denaturation and degradation. The amorphous MOFs (aMOFs) with disordered and fuzzy structures had been utilized as a host of enzymes, which maintained a higher activity of enzymes than that in crystalline MOFs and showed good stability. Compared with other enzyme immobilization carriers, such as polymeric matrices, nanomaterials, porous materials, and microcapsules, aMOFs can reduce the leach of the enzyme, enzyme denaturation, and the restricted mass transfer efficiency, and can improve the operational stability of enzymes in harsh environments. aMOFs can be synthesized through the amorphization of MOFs, such as pressure/heat-induced amorphization, mechanical milling-induced amorphization, chemical treatment-induced amorphization, and the direct synthesis of aMOFs. However, most approaches need harsh conditions to synthesize aMOFs, which are detrimental to biomacromolecules. Thus, a mild method is necessary for the immobilization of enzymes.

elements.content: Enzymes are widely applied in medicine, agriculture, and food processing; however, the catalytic activities of enzymes are usually lost after exposure to harsh conditions. Currently, huge efforts have been devoted to the investigation of efficient artificial enzymes (nanozymes), which possess enzymelike activities and stability in harsh environments. For example, several nanoparticles have been found to exhibit enzyme-like activity, such as Au NPs and MnO2 that possess oxidase-like activity, as well as Fe3O4 and TiO2 that possess mimetic horseradish peroxidase (HRP) activity. Although great development has been achieved, the types of reaction that can be catalyzed by enzymes are still limited; thus, to realize practical applications, it is essential to make the nanozyme particles realize extended applications in the enzyme/nanozyme cascade. For example, the enzyme/nanozyme cascade has been applied in the detection of glucose with improved performance when compared with total natural enzymes; however, with few reports, the enzyme/nanozyme cascade is still in its infancy, and the main issue is the lack of techniques to confine the cascade reaction. Owing to the favorable biocompatibility, enough space for hosting, and the confinement in a dimensional structure, MOFs can be used to enhance the stability of both enzymes and nanozymes. Consequently, the prospect of a cascade catalytic reaction of natural enzymes and nanozymes encapsulated in MOFs is promising.

elements.content: Diabetes mellitus, caused by abnormal levels of insulin endocranium, is a global health concern that affects almost 10% of the world population. Over the past decades, huge efforts have been devoted to improving the performance of glucose sensors, and currently, the most common method for serum glucose detection is the two-enzyme cascade reaction (GOx/HRP). However, the shortcomings of this approach are that enzymes are expensive and the activity is sensitive to environments, which causes limited detection accuracy that hinders the point-of-care test (POCT) of serum glucose levels. Thus, to develop a glucose sensor with high simplicity, sensitivity, reliability, and stability, it is necessary to discover ways to protect the enzyme cascade.

elements.content: Herein, we report a mild one-pot approach, with which we can in situ package the enzymes in aMOFs. Amorphous ZIF-90 (aZIF-90) was used to confine the natural/mimetic enzyme cascade (GOx/MNP), and we used the simple colorimetric assay to detect the concentration of glucose, which substituted the magnetic nanoparticles (Fe3O4, MNP) for HRP. The resulting GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 nanocomposite exhibits 3 times higher activity than that in crystalline MOFs and 4 times higher activity than the cascade of free GOx and MNP. Via a magnetic field, the magnetic framework composites (MFCs) can be easily recovered with minimal loss.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we report a mild one-pot approach, with which we can in situ package the enzymes in aMOFs. Amorphous ZIF-90 (aZIF-90) was used to confine the natural/mimetic enzyme cascade (GOx/MNP), and we used the simple colorimetric assay to detect the concentration of glucose, which substituted the magnetic nanoparticles (Fe3O4, MNP) for HRP. The resulting GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 nanocomposite exhibits 3 times higher activity than that in crystalline MOFs and 4 times higher activity than the cascade of free GOx and MNP. Via a magnetic field, the magnetic framework composites (MFCs) can be easily recovered with minimal loss.

elements.content: This is the first time that natural/mimetic enzymes were simultaneously encapsulated in aZIF-90 through the coprecipitation method under mild conditions. The resulting amorphous composites demonstrated a reasonable protective capability compared with the crude counterpart and higher glucose sensitivity with simpler operations. The limit of glucose detection was determined to be 0.319 μM and the linear range was 0.038–34 μM. In conclusion, we have synthesized aZIF-90, which could be a useful instrument for the package of enzymes and nanozymes (). Glucose is first oxidized by GOx to generate the side product H2O2. Subsequently, Fe3O4 MNP could catalyze the H2O2-mediated oxidation of TMB and yield the oxidized colored product oxTMB, which exhibits maximum absorption at 652 nm. Thus, glucose detection could be achieved in this colorimetric manner.

elements.content: Zinc nitrate (214.2 mg) was added into DI water (3.0 mL) as a triggered solvent. Then, this solution was added to DI water (21 mL) in which ICA (276.8 mg) was dissolved. The reaction mixture was stirred for 12 h at room temperature at 300 rpm. Then, the ZIF-90 product was collected via centrifugation at 8000 rpm, 6 min, and washed three times with DI water. The amorphous ZIF-90 was synthesized by the same approach but the molar ratio between ICA and Zn2+ was 1:1.
elements.clean_text:
Materials and Methods

Synthesis of ZIF-90 and aZIF-90

Zinc nitrate (214.2 mg) was added into DI water (3.0 mL) as a triggered solvent. Then, this solution was added to DI water (21 mL) in which ICA (276.8 mg) was dissolved. The reaction mixture was stirred for 12 h at room temperature at 300 rpm. Then, the ZIF-90 product was collected via centrifugation at 8000 rpm, 6 min, and washed three times with DI water. The amorphous ZIF-90 was synthesized by the same approach but the molar ratio between ICA and Zn2+ was 1:1.

elements.content: GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 nanocomposites were synthesized as follows: zinc nitrate (214.2 mg) was added into DI water (3.0 mL) as a triggered solvent. Then, this solution was added to DI water (21 mL) in which ICA (69.2 mg), MNP (7.2 mL, 1 mg/mL), and GOx (12 mg) were dissolved. The reaction mixture was stirred for 12 h at room temperature at 300 rpm. Then, the product was collected via a magnetic field and washed three times with DI water. After the process of encapsulation and wash, the supernatant of the reaction solution was collected to calculate the loading efficiency (LE %) with the use of the Bradford kit (Figure S1, methodology detailed in Supplementary Methods, eq 1).
elements.clean_text:
Fabrication of GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 Nanocomposites

GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 nanocomposites were synthesized as follows: zinc nitrate (214.2 mg) was added into DI water (3.0 mL) as a triggered solvent. Then, this solution was added to DI water (21 mL) in which ICA (69.2 mg), MNP (7.2 mL, 1 mg/mL), and GOx (12 mg) were dissolved. The reaction mixture was stirred for 12 h at room temperature at 300 rpm. Then, the product was collected via a magnetic field and washed three times with DI water. After the process of encapsulation and wash, the supernatant of the reaction solution was collected to calculate the loading efficiency (LE %) with the use of the Bradford kit (Figure S1, methodology detailed in Supplementary Methods, eq 1).

Cascade Catalytic Reaction of Glucose Sensing

elements.content: The substrate glucose (180 μL, 10 mM) was mixed with GOx/MNP@MOF nanocomposites (25 μL, 1 mg/mL), Tris–HCl buffer (250 μL, pH 3.0), and TMB solution (35 μL, 8 mM) and the mixture was kept in an oscillating metal bath at 37 °C. After 15 min of incubation, the reaction was separated with a magnetic field, and the blue supernatant (oxTMB) was utilized to calculate the cascade catalytic activity at 652 nm using a microplate reader (Biotek Synergy H1). Similarly, cascade catalytic activities of free natural enzymes and nanozymes were conducted utilizing the above-mentioned method.

After 15 min of incubation, the reaction was separated with a magnetic field, and the blue supernatant (oxTMB) was utilized to calculate the cascade catalytic activity at 652 nm using a microplate reader (Biotek Synergy H1). Similarly, cascade catalytic activities of free natural enzymes and nanozymes were conducted utilizing the above-mentioned method.

elements.content: The crystallinity of GOx/MNP@ZIF-90 with different molar ratios of ICA and Zn2+ was examined through X-ray diffraction analysis (). The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) spectra indicate that the crystallinity decreased as ICA and Zn2+ decreased. When the ratio between ICA and Zn2+ was 2:1, the crystalline structure of ZIF-90 was synthesized. When the ratio between ICA and Zn2+ was lowered to 1:1 and 0.6:1, the prominent peaks disappeared while the peaks corresponding to the planes (2 2 0), (3 1 1), and (4 0 0) emerged, which were attributed to the presence of MNP. Therefore, we had a wild guess that we have synthesized aZIF-90 with a random network topology rather than the sodalite topology of crystal ZIF-90 under mild aqueous conditions.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

XRD Study

The crystallinity of GOx/MNP@ZIF-90 with different molar ratios of ICA and Zn2+ was examined through X-ray diffraction analysis (). The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) spectra indicate that the crystallinity decreased as ICA and Zn2+ decreased. When the ratio between ICA and Zn2+ was 2:1, the crystalline structure of ZIF-90 was synthesized. When the ratio between ICA and Zn2+ was lowered to 1:1 and 0.6:1, the prominent peaks disappeared while the peaks corresponding to the planes (2 2 0), (3 1 1), and (4 0 0) emerged, which were attributed to the presence of MNP. Therefore, we had a wild guess that we have synthesized aZIF-90 with a random network topology rather than the sodalite topology of crystal ZIF-90 under mild aqueous conditions.

Thus, according to the literature, we studied the chemical bonding information of Zn to find out whether the bond of Zn and N still existed in the amorphous framework structure.
elements.clean_text:
XPS and FT-IR Analysis

As indicated by XRD patterns, the long-distance order disappeared, which makes it difficult to characterize the amorphous ZIF-90. Thus, according to the literature, we studied the chemical bonding information of Zn to find out whether the bond of Zn and N still existed in the amorphous framework structure.

elements.content: X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to investigate the chemical composition and oxidation states of ZIF-90, aZIF-90, and GOx/MNP@aZIF-90. As shown in the XPS spectra in A, similar coordination between Zn and N was present in amorphous ZIF-90 as in the ZIF-90. The Zn 2p peak is at 1021.63 eV (B), slightly lower than the standard binding energy of Zn2+ (1022 eV), which also showed the chemical environment of Zn to be Zn–N. As shown in C, the XPS spectrum showed the presence of four characteristic peaks at 709.59, 711.18, 723.03, and 724.83 eV, which belong to the Fe­(II) 2p3/2, Fe­(III) 2p3/2, Fe­(II) 2p1/2, and Fe­(III) 2p1/2 spin–orbit peaks of Fe3O4, confirming that the final composites were formed with the mixed oxides of Fe­(II) and Fe­(III). As shown in Table S1, the chemical composition has been calculated for each sample through the integration of the peak area of the elements (C, Zn, N, Fe, P, S). The presence of Fe, P, and S elements is indicative of the successful immobilization of MNP and GOx.

The Zn 2p peak is at 1021.63 eV (B), slightly lower than the standard binding energy of Zn2+ (1022 eV), which also showed the chemical environment of Zn to be Zn-N. As shown in C, the XPS spectrum showed the presence of four characteristic peaks at 709.59, 711.18, 723.03, and 724.83 eV, which belong to the Fe(II) 2p3/2, Fe(III) 2p3/2, Fe(II) 2p1/2, and Fe(III) 2p1/2 spin-orbit peaks of Fe3O4, confirming that the final composites were formed with the mixed oxides of Fe(II) and Fe(III). As shown in Table S1, the chemical composition has been calculated for each sample through the integration of the peak area of the elements (C, Zn, N, Fe, P, S). The presence of Fe, P, and S elements is indicative of the successful immobilization of MNP and GOx.

elements.content: To further testify the successfully synthesized amorphous ZIF-90, the chemical bonding information of Zn was investigated by FT-IR. As shown in D, the FT-IR structures of ZIF-90 and aZIF-90 were similar. As for ZIF-90 and aZIF-90, the strong peaks at 422, 1460, and 1668 cm–1 could be attributed to the stretching of Zn–N, C–N, and the aldehyde stretch of the imidazole ligands, respectively. In MNP, the band at 605 cm–1 was associated with Fe–O bonds, which indicated the immobilization of MNP.

elements.content: The morphologies of GOx/MNP@aZIF-9, ZIF-9, and aZIF-90 were determined by SEM and TEM characterization (A–F). From the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern of aZIF-90, no visible diffraction rings were found, which could further testify the existence of the amorphous structure rather than the crystalline structure. The sizes of particles were measured with dynamic light scattering (DLS), and the aZIF-90 showed a well-distributed size with an average size around 1250 nm. In an aqueous solution, the particles have slight agglomeration, which might be the reason why the particle sizes are larger than those obtained from SEM images (Figure S2). The spatial distribution of GOx within GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 and GOx/MNP@ZIF-90 was assessed using fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC)-tagged enzymes and confocal laser microscopy (CLSM, Figure S3). As shown in the images, FITC-tagged GOx molecules were mainly embedded in the particle center of the nanocomposites.
elements.clean_text:
Characterization of Morphologies

The morphologies of GOx/MNP@aZIF-9, ZIF-9, and aZIF-90 were determined by SEM and TEM characterization (A-F). From the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern of aZIF-90, no visible diffraction rings were found, which could further testify the existence of the amorphous structure rather than the crystalline structure. The sizes of particles were measured with dynamic light scattering (DLS), and the aZIF-90 showed a well-distributed size with an average size around 1250 nm. In an aqueous solution, the particles have slight agglomeration, which might be the reason why the particle sizes are larger than those obtained from SEM images (Figure S2). The spatial distribution of GOx within GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 and GOx/MNP@ZIF-90 was assessed using fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC)-tagged enzymes and confocal laser microscopy (CLSM, Figure S3). As shown in the images, FITC-tagged GOx molecules were mainly embedded in the particle center of the nanocomposites.

From the data of aZIF-90, it was evident that micropores from 1 to 2 nm disappeared and the mesopores from 5 to 20 nm were increased.

elements.content: We utilized a vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM) to investigate the magnetic properties of MNP@aZIF-90, GOx/MNP@aZIF-90, and MNP. The saturation magnetization (M s) values of MNP@aZIF-90 and GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 were lower than the M s values of MNP (C,D), which could be attributed to the encapsulation in the aZIF-90 resulting in a reduction in the surface moments of individual particles. However, magnetic composites could still show a quick response to a magnetic field while lowering of the M s values.

The saturation magnetization (M s) values of MNP@aZIF-90 and GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 were lower than the M s values of MNP (C,D), which could be attributed to the encapsulation in the aZIF-90 resulting in a reduction in the surface moments of individual particles. However, magnetic composites could still show a quick response to a magnetic field while lowering of the M s values.

elements.content: To investigate the activity of the MOF-confined cascade reactions (GOx/MNP@MOF), the catalytic oxidation of the substrate (TMB) was tested in the presence of glucose. Meanwhile, the catalytic oxidation of TMB without the MOF-confined composite (GOx@MOF|MNP) was considered as the control experiment. By measuring the change of absorbance at 652 nm (A,B), it was found that the cascade catalytic activity of GOx/MNP@MOF was significantly higher than that of GOx@MOF|MNP, which indicated that the chemical environment of the MOF-confined composite could support the proximity between the natural and mimetic enzymes, resulting in the enhancement of the catalyzing activity. In addition, the oxidation of TMB using different combinations of GOx and MNP and different substrates has been utilized to testify the advantage of aZIF-90 (Figure S4). We used glucose and H2O2 as substrates and controlled the identical molar ratios of substrates in reactions. Then, the catalyzed activity was measured through the absorbance of oxTMB at 652 nm. As shown in the image, these results confirmed that the MOF could minimize the denaturation and destruction of enzymes, and the mimic enzymes (MNP) showed better stability than the natural enzymes (GOx).
elements.clean_text:
Verification of MOF-Confined Cascade Reactions

To investigate the activity of the MOF-confined cascade reactions (GOx/MNP@MOF), the catalytic oxidation of the substrate (TMB) was tested in the presence of glucose. Meanwhile, the catalytic oxidation of TMB without the MOF-confined composite (GOx@MOF|MNP) was considered as the control experiment. By measuring the change of absorbance at 652 nm (A,B), it was found that the cascade catalytic activity of GOx/MNP@MOF was significantly higher than that of GOx@MOF|MNP, which indicated that the chemical environment of the MOF-confined composite could support the proximity between the natural and mimetic enzymes, resulting in the enhancement of the catalyzing activity. In addition, the oxidation of TMB using different combinations of GOx and MNP and different substrates has been utilized to testify the advantage of aZIF-90 (Figure S4). We used glucose and H2O2 as substrates and controlled the identical molar ratios of substrates in reactions. Then, the catalyzed activity was measured through the absorbance of oxTMB at 652 nm. As shown in the image, these results confirmed that the MOF could minimize the denaturation and destruction of enzymes, and the mimic enzymes (MNP) showed better stability than the natural enzymes (GOx).

elements.clean_text:
Optimizing the Response of the GOx/MNP@MOF Nanocomposite toward Glucose

MOFs like ZIF-8, ZIF-90, and MAF-7 have been utilized as common host materials to protect the biomacromolecules from harsh conditions. However, when it comes to the encapsulation of a certain biomacromolecule, different MOFs usually exhibit different performances. Therefore, it is critical to screen the most suitable MOF to encapsulate the GOx/MNP cascade. To examine the influence of the MOF that encapsulates the GOx and MNP, three biocompatible MOFs (ZIF-8, ZIF-90, MAF-7) were screened. As shown in Figure S5A, the cascade catalytic activity of GOx/MNP@ZIF-90 was higher than those of GOx/MNP@ZIF-8 and GOx/MNP@MAF-7. The immobilization rate of GOx in the three MOFs was analyzed, and we found that ZIF-90 yielded the highest immobilization rate (Figure S5B). As a biocompatible material, ZIF-90 exhibited a designable structure and topology, good hydrophilia, and weaker interactions between the enzyme and material, which has been widely used in the encapsulation of enzymes including horseradish peroxidase, catalase, and lipase.

elements.content: The screening indicates that ZIF-90 is more suitable for the co-encapsulation of GOx and MNP when compared with others, which could be derived from the chemically organic links that significantly modify the hydrophilicity of ZIF-90. Recently, it was found that the activity of the MOF-based nanocomposite could be manipulated by altering the ratios of the metal node and the organic linker in MOF fabrication. Especially, some reports reasoned that the decrease of the organic linker amount helps in forming amorphous MOFs, which usually brings a significant increase in maintaining the activity of MOF-encapsulated enzymes. Inspired by the intriguing phenomena, we then investigated the influence of the ratios of the metal node (Zn) and the organic linker (ICA) in ZIF-90 fabrication.

Recently, it was found that the activity of the MOF-based nanocomposite could be manipulated by altering the ratios of the metal node and the organic linker in MOF fabrication. Especially, some reports reasoned that the decrease of the organic linker amount helps in forming amorphous MOFs, which usually brings a significant increase in maintaining the activity of MOF-encapsulated enzymes. Inspired by the intriguing phenomena, we then investigated the influence of the ratios of the metal node (Zn) and the organic linker (ICA) in ZIF-90 fabrication.

elements.content: Six different ICA/Zn2+ ratios (1:1, 2:1, 3:1, 4:1, 5:1, and 6:1) were examined, and the results are shown in ; the activity increases while the ICA/Zn2+ ratios decrease, especially when the ICA/Zn2+ ratio is 1:1. To avoid different quantities of loading enzymes that could influence the catalytic results, we investigated the immobilization rate of GOx in different ICA/Zn2+ molar ratios (Figure S6). As the data have shown, the composites with different ICA/Zn2+ ratios have similar immobilization rates, which means the improvement of the catalytic activity is not related to the encapsulation rate of GOx. Then, the chemical environment of ZIF-90 with ICA/Zn2+ at a ratio of 1:1 was investigated. It was found, through the characterization of XRD, FT-IR, and XPS, that we have synthesized amorphous ZIF-90. The obtained GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 nanocomposite exhibits almost 4 times higher apparent activity than the crystalline GOx/MNP@ZIF-90, which might be attributed to the generation of mesopores. Meanwhile, after three successive cycles of reuse, the residual GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 still reserved 98% activity.

elements.content: To examine the influence of the amounts of GOx and MNP on the activity of the composite, three different amounts of GOx and MNP were examined, and the composite fabrications were conducted following the protocol described in section with ICA and Zn at a ratio of 1:1. As shown in A, under a fixed concentration of MNP, the activity increased accordingly when more GOx was added and vice versa. As the amount of GOx reached 0.5 mg/mL, 0.3 and 0.5 mg/mL MNP yielded similar activities, which could be derived from the near-saturated encapsulation. Balancing the reagent cost and the sensor performance, 0.5 mg/mL GOx and 0.3 mg/mL MNP were adopted.

elements.content: To study the influence of the thermal treatment on the cascade catalytic activity of GOx/MNP@aZIF-90, the incubation temperature ranging from 37 to 87 °C was considered (increasing 10 °C per stage). According to B, the highest activity was exhibited at 37 °C; thus, 37 °C was considered as the optimum incubation temperature to catalyze the cascade reaction. Moreover, GOx is not a thermal-stable enzyme, while the activity of the composite at 77 °C still retained 85% of the activity at 37 °C, which suggested that ZIF-90 is a good host material to protect GOx in harsh conditions. The significant protection under thermal conditions could be derived from the artful pore of ZIF-90, which provides a rigid structure to prevent enzymes from harsh factors.

elements.content: To analyze the influence of the pH conditions on the cascade catalytic activity, six different pH conditions (3, 4, 5, 7, 9, and 10) have been examined. As demonstrated in C, GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 exhibited better tolerance in an acidic condition, and the activity was the highest when the pH was 3. The enhancement of acid stability could be attributed to the confinement of GOx and MNP in a three-dimensional structure, which can minimize the unfolding of the enzyme.

elements.content: Kinetic constants of enzymes have been determined and are listed in Table S2; the V max value of GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 is 4.54 μM/min, and the K m value of GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 is 0.265 μM (methodology detailed in Supplementary Methods, eq 2). Compared to other approaches, amorphous ZIF-90 showed the potential to be a powerful tool compared to other materials. As shown in A, the absorbance of samples increases as the concentrations of glucose increase. The linear relationship could be established from 0.038 to 34 μM, and the limit of detection (LOD) of 0.319 μM was obtained following the 3σ/slope rule (methodology detailed in Supplementary Methods, eq 3). Crystalline GOx/HRP@ZIF-8 shows good selectivity toward glucose, and the nanocomposites GOx/FeNi-MOF also performed well in the detection of glucose. However, compared with other approaches, GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 showed a lower limit of detection, which could be ascribed to the expanded pore size of aZIF-90 that could facilitate substrate transportation and the internal voids that could provide sufficient space for multienzymes (, methodology detailed in Supplementary Methods).

elements.content: Long-term storage stability and recyclability are two important aspects for developing a reliable biosensor. Thus, to analyze the storage stability and recyclability, nanocomposites were stored for 12 days and reused 6 times, respectively. As shown in C, GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 retained ∼70% of the initial overall activity for 12 days at 4 °C, while GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 retained ∼65% of the initial overall activity after 6 cycles of reuse (D). The significant enhancement of stability might be attributed to the rigid structure of MOF, which restrains the enzyme structure from unfolding and avoids the leakage of enzymes through rigid restriction.
elements.clean_text:
Storage Stability and Recyclability of Nanocomposites (GOx/MNP@aZIF-90)

Long-term storage stability and recyclability are two important aspects for developing a reliable biosensor. Thus, to analyze the storage stability and recyclability, nanocomposites were stored for 12 days and reused 6 times, respectively. As shown in C, GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 retained ~70% of the initial overall activity for 12 days at 4 °C, while GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 retained ~65% of the initial overall activity after 6 cycles of reuse (D). The significant enhancement of stability might be attributed to the rigid structure of MOF, which restrains the enzyme structure from unfolding and avoids the leakage of enzymes through rigid restriction.

elements.content: In this research, amorphous ZIF-90 was utilized to encapsulate the mimic enzyme (MNP) and natural enzyme (GOx) together to fabricate an enzymatic cascade system. It was found that aZIF-90 not only provided a shell to confine the cascade reaction but also enhanced the catalytic ability of the GOx and MNP cascade. GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 exhibits almost 4 times higher catalytic activity than that of the crystalline composite (GOx/MNP@ZIF-90), and the residual activity was higher than 80% after the biosensor was stored for 9 days. Compared with ZIF-90, which exhibits micropores ranging from 1 to 2 nm, aZIF-90 showed mesopores ranging from 5 to 20 nm, which significantly facilitate the delivery of the substrate, thus enhancing the activity of confined enzymes. Additionally, it was reasoned that the internal voids in aZIF-90 provide sufficient space for multienzymes and minimize the activity loss of confined enzymes. In summary, a biocompatible, stable, simple, and low-cost strategy has been developed to synthesize amorphous ZIF-90 for the package of enzymes and nanozymes, which might be a potential tool for enzymatic catalysis in industries.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this research, amorphous ZIF-90 was utilized to encapsulate the mimic enzyme (MNP) and natural enzyme (GOx) together to fabricate an enzymatic cascade system. It was found that aZIF-90 not only provided a shell to confine the cascade reaction but also enhanced the catalytic ability of the GOx and MNP cascade. GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 exhibits almost 4 times higher catalytic activity than that of the crystalline composite (GOx/MNP@ZIF-90), and the residual activity was higher than 80% after the biosensor was stored for 9 days. Compared with ZIF-90, which exhibits micropores ranging from 1 to 2 nm, aZIF-90 showed mesopores ranging from 5 to 20 nm, which significantly facilitate the delivery of the substrate, thus enhancing the activity of confined enzymes. Additionally, it was reasoned that the internal voids in aZIF-90 provide sufficient space for multienzymes and minimize the activity loss of confined enzymes. In summary, a biocompatible, stable, simple, and low-cost strategy has been developed to synthesize amorphous ZIF-90 for the package of enzymes and nanozymes, which might be a potential tool for enzymatic catalysis in industries.

cln_elements.content: Zinc nitrate (214.2 mg) was added into DI water (3.0 mL) as a triggered solvent. Then, this solution was added to DI water (21 mL) in which ICA (276.8 mg) was dissolved. The reaction mixture was stirred for 12 h at room temperature at 300 rpm. Then, the ZIF-90 product was collected via centrifugation at 8000 rpm, 6 min, and washed three times with DI water. The amorphous ZIF-90 was synthesized by the same approach but the molar ratio between ICA and Zn2+ was 1:1.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Materials and Methods

Synthesis of ZIF-90 and aZIF-90

Zinc nitrate (214.2 mg) was added into DI water (3.0 mL) as a triggered solvent. Then, this solution was added to DI water (21 mL) in which ICA (276.8 mg) was dissolved. The reaction mixture was stirred for 12 h at room temperature at 300 rpm. Then, the ZIF-90 product was collected via centrifugation at 8000 rpm, 6 min, and washed three times with DI water. The amorphous ZIF-90 was synthesized by the same approach but the molar ratio between ICA and Zn2+ was 1:1.

cln_elements.content:
This is the first time that natural/mimetic enzymes were simultaneously encapsulated in aZIF-90 through the coprecipitation method under mild conditions. The resulting amorphous composites demonstrated a reasonable protective capability compared with the crude counterpart and higher glucose sensitivity with simpler operations. The limit of glucose detection was determined to be 0.319 μM and the linear range was 0.038–34 μM. In conclusion, we have synthesized aZIF-90, which could be a useful instrument for the package of enzymes and nanozymes (). Glucose is first oxidized by GOx to generate the side product H2O2. Subsequently, Fe3O4 MNP could catalyze the H2O2-mediated oxidation of TMB and yield the oxidized colored product oxTMB, which exhibits maximum absorption at 652 nm. Thus, glucose detection could be achieved in this colorimetric manner.

We utilized a vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM) to investigate the magnetic properties of MNP@aZIF-90, GOx/MNP@aZIF-90, and MNP. The saturation magnetization (M s) values of MNP@aZIF-90 and GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 were lower than the M s values of MNP (C,D), which could be attributed to the encapsulation in the aZIF-90 resulting in a reduction in the surface moments of individual particles. However, magnetic composites could still show a quick response to a magnetic field while lowering of the M s values.

Analytical Performance

Kinetic constants of enzymes have been determined and are listed in Table S2; the V max value of GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 is 4.54 μM/min, and the K m value of GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 is 0.265 μM (methodology detailed in Supplementary Methods, eq 2). Compared to other approaches, amorphous ZIF-90 showed the potential to be a powerful tool compared to other materials. As shown in A, the absorbance of samples increases as the concentrations of glucose increase. The linear relationship could be established from 0.038 to 34 μM, and the limit of detection (LOD) of 0.319 μM was obtained following the 3σ/slope rule (methodology detailed in Supplementary Methods, eq 3). Crystalline GOx/HRP@ZIF-8 shows good selectivity toward glucose, and the nanocomposites GOx/FeNi-MOF also performed well in the detection of glucose. However, compared with other approaches, GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 showed a lower limit of detection, which could be ascribed to the expanded pore size of aZIF-90 that could facilitate substrate transportation and the internal voids that could provide sufficient space for multienzymes (, methodology detailed in Supplementary Methods).

Storage Stability and Recyclability of Nanocomposites (GOx/MNP@aZIF-90)

Long-term storage stability and recyclability are two important aspects for developing a reliable biosensor. Thus, to analyze the storage stability and recyclability, nanocomposites were stored for 12 days and reused 6 times, respectively. As shown in C, GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 retained ∼70% of the initial overall activity for 12 days at 4 °C, while GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 retained ∼65% of the initial overall activity after 6 cycles of reuse (D). The significant enhancement of stability might be attributed to the rigid structure of MOF, which restrains the enzyme structure from unfolding and avoids the leakage of enzymes through rigid restriction.

Conclusions

In this research, amorphous ZIF-90 was utilized to encapsulate the mimic enzyme (MNP) and natural enzyme (GOx) together to fabricate an enzymatic cascade system. It was found that aZIF-90 not only provided a shell to confine the cascade reaction but also enhanced the catalytic ability of the GOx and MNP cascade. GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 exhibits almost 4 times higher catalytic activity than that of the crystalline composite (GOx/MNP@ZIF-90), and the residual activity was higher than 80% after the biosensor was stored for 9 days. Compared with ZIF-90, which exhibits micropores ranging from 1 to 2 nm, aZIF-90 showed mesopores ranging from 5 to 20 nm, which significantly facilitate the delivery of the substrate, thus enhancing the activity of confined enzymes. Additionally, it was reasoned that the internal voids in aZIF-90 provide sufficient space for multienzymes and minimize the activity loss of confined enzymes. In summary, a biocompatible, stable, simple, and low-cost strategy has been developed to synthesize amorphous ZIF-90 for the package of enzymes and nanozymes, which might be a potential tool for enzymatic catalysis in industries.
cln_elements.clean_text:
This is the first time that natural/mimetic enzymes were simultaneously encapsulated in aZIF-90 through the coprecipitation method under mild conditions. The resulting amorphous composites demonstrated a reasonable protective capability compared with the crude counterpart and higher glucose sensitivity with simpler operations. The limit of glucose detection was determined to be 0.319 μM and the linear range was 0.038-34 μM. In conclusion, we have synthesized aZIF-90, which could be a useful instrument for the package of enzymes and nanozymes (). Glucose is first oxidized by GOx to generate the side product H2O2. Subsequently, Fe3O4 MNP could catalyze the H2O2-mediated oxidation of TMB and yield the oxidized colored product oxTMB, which exhibits maximum absorption at 652 nm. Thus, glucose detection could be achieved in this colorimetric manner.

We utilized a vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM) to investigate the magnetic properties of MNP@aZIF-90, GOx/MNP@aZIF-90, and MNP. The saturation magnetization (M s) values of MNP@aZIF-90 and GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 were lower than the M s values of MNP (C,D), which could be attributed to the encapsulation in the aZIF-90 resulting in a reduction in the surface moments of individual particles. However, magnetic composites could still show a quick response to a magnetic field while lowering of the M s values.

Analytical Performance

Kinetic constants of enzymes have been determined and are listed in Table S2; the V max value of GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 is 4.54 μM/min, and the K m value of GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 is 0.265 μM (methodology detailed in Supplementary Methods, eq 2). Compared to other approaches, amorphous ZIF-90 showed the potential to be a powerful tool compared to other materials. As shown in A, the absorbance of samples increases as the concentrations of glucose increase. The linear relationship could be established from 0.038 to 34 μM, and the limit of detection (LOD) of 0.319 μM was obtained following the 3σ/slope rule (methodology detailed in Supplementary Methods, eq 3). Crystalline GOx/HRP@ZIF-8 shows good selectivity toward glucose, and the nanocomposites GOx/FeNi-MOF also performed well in the detection of glucose. However, compared with other approaches, GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 showed a lower limit of detection, which could be ascribed to the expanded pore size of aZIF-90 that could facilitate substrate transportation and the internal voids that could provide sufficient space for multienzymes (, methodology detailed in Supplementary Methods).

Storage Stability and Recyclability of Nanocomposites (GOx/MNP@aZIF-90)

Long-term storage stability and recyclability are two important aspects for developing a reliable biosensor. Thus, to analyze the storage stability and recyclability, nanocomposites were stored for 12 days and reused 6 times, respectively. As shown in C, GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 retained ~70% of the initial overall activity for 12 days at 4 °C, while GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 retained ~65% of the initial overall activity after 6 cycles of reuse (D). The significant enhancement of stability might be attributed to the rigid structure of MOF, which restrains the enzyme structure from unfolding and avoids the leakage of enzymes through rigid restriction. 

Conclusions

In this research, amorphous ZIF-90 was utilized to encapsulate the mimic enzyme (MNP) and natural enzyme (GOx) together to fabricate an enzymatic cascade system. It was found that aZIF-90 not only provided a shell to confine the cascade reaction but also enhanced the catalytic ability of the GOx and MNP cascade. GOx/MNP@aZIF-90 exhibits almost 4 times higher catalytic activity than that of the crystalline composite (GOx/MNP@ZIF-90), and the residual activity was higher than 80% after the biosensor was stored for 9 days. Compared with ZIF-90, which exhibits micropores ranging from 1 to 2 nm, aZIF-90 showed mesopores ranging from 5 to 20 nm, which significantly facilitate the delivery of the substrate, thus enhancing the activity of confined enzymes. Additionally, it was reasoned that the internal voids in aZIF-90 provide sufficient space for multienzymes and minimize the activity loss of confined enzymes. In summary, a biocompatible, stable, simple, and low-cost strategy has been developed to synthesize amorphous ZIF-90 for the package of enzymes and nanozymes, which might be a potential tool for enzymatic catalysis in industries.
